content:
PopupEventArgs Class

In this Article

Provides data for the Popup event.

Syntax

Declaration

public class PopupEventArgs : System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • Object
  • EventArgs
  • System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs
  • PopupEventArgs

Inherited Members

Cancel
,
Empty
,
Equals(Object)
,
Equals(Object,Object)
,
GetHashCode()
,
GetType()
,
MemberwiseClone()
,
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
,
ToString()

Remarks

The Popup event of the ToolTip class is raised before a ToolTip is displayed. The handler for this event receives a parameter of type PopupEventArgs. This parameter provides information about the ToolTip and enables you to modify the size of the ToolTip through the ToolTipSize property. Because Popup derives from CancelEventArgs, the handler can also stop the ToolTip from being displayed.

Constructors summary

PopupEventArgs(IWin32Window,Control,Boolean,Size)

Initializes an instance of the PopupEventArgs class.

Properties summary

AssociatedControl

Gets the control for which the ToolTip is being drawn.
AssociatedWindow

Gets the window to which this ToolTip is bound.
IsBalloon

Gets a value indicating whether the ToolTip is displayed as a standard rectangular or a balloon window.
ToolTipSize

Gets or sets the size of the ToolTip.

Constructors

  • PopupEventArgs(IWin32Window,Control,Boolean,Size)

    Initializes an instance of the PopupEventArgs class.

    public PopupEventArgs (System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window associatedWindow, System.Windows.Forms.Control associatedControl, bool isBalloon, System.Drawing.Size size);

    Parameters

    • associatedWindow
      IWin32Window

      The IWin32Window that the ToolTip is bound to.

    • associatedControl
      Control

      The Control that the ToolTip is being created for.

    • isBalloon
      Boolean

      true to indicate that the associated ToolTip window has a balloon-style appearance; otherwise, false to indicate that the ToolTip window has a standard rectangular appearance.

    • size
      Size

      The Size of the ToolTip.

    Remarks

    The parameters to the PopupEventArgs constructor are used to initialize the corresponding, similarly named properties. The associatedControl parameter can be null if the owning window is not of type Control.

Properties

  • AssociatedControl

    Gets the control for which the ToolTip is being drawn.

    public System.Windows.Forms.Control AssociatedControl { get; }

    Property Value

    • Control

      The Control that is associated with the ToolTip, or null if the ToolTip is not associated with a control.

    Remarks

    Because you can associate the ToolTip with multiple controls through the SetToolTip method, you can use the AssociatedControl property to determine which control the Draw event is associated with. This is helpful if you want to perform different ToolTip customization based on the associated control.

    Example

    The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip.Popup event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing Show with WriteLine or appending the message to a multiline TextBox.

    To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type ToolTip named ToolTip1. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip.Popup event. 

    private void ToolTip1_Popup(Object sender, PopupEventArgs e) {

System.Text.StringBuilder messageBoxCS = new System.Text.StringBuilder();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "ToolTipSize", e.ToolTipSize );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "Cancel", e.Cancel );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
MessageBox.Show(messageBoxCS.ToString(), "Popup Event" );
}

    Private Sub ToolTip1_Popup(sender as Object, e as PopupEventArgs) _ 
     Handles ToolTip1.Popup

    Dim messageBoxVB as New System.Text.StringBuilder()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "ToolTipSize", e.ToolTipSize)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "Cancel", e.Cancel)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    MessageBox.Show(messageBoxVB.ToString(),"Popup Event")

End Sub
  • AssociatedWindow

    Gets the window to which this ToolTip is bound.

    public System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window AssociatedWindow { get; }

    Property Value

    • IWin32Window

      The window which owns the ToolTip.

    Remarks

    When a window is owned by another window, the owned window is minimized and closed with the owner window. Owned windows are also never displayed behind their owner form. In this case, the ToolTip is owned by the native Win32 window, represented by the AssociatedWindow property.

    Example

    The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip.Popup event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing Show with WriteLine or appending the message to a multiline TextBox.

    To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type ToolTip named ToolTip1. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip.Popup event. 

    private void ToolTip1_Popup(Object sender, PopupEventArgs e) {

System.Text.StringBuilder messageBoxCS = new System.Text.StringBuilder();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "ToolTipSize", e.ToolTipSize );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "Cancel", e.Cancel );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
MessageBox.Show(messageBoxCS.ToString(), "Popup Event" );
}

    Private Sub ToolTip1_Popup(sender as Object, e as PopupEventArgs) _ 
     Handles ToolTip1.Popup

    Dim messageBoxVB as New System.Text.StringBuilder()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "ToolTipSize", e.ToolTipSize)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "Cancel", e.Cancel)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    MessageBox.Show(messageBoxVB.ToString(),"Popup Event")

End Sub
  • IsBalloon

    Gets a value indicating whether the ToolTip is displayed as a standard rectangular or a balloon window.

    public bool IsBalloon { get; }

    Property Value

    • Boolean

      true if the ToolTip is displayed in a balloon window; otherwise, false if a standard rectangular window is used.

    Remarks

    The type of window used for the ToolTip is specified in the IsBalloon method of the ToolTip class.

    Example

    The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip.Popup event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing Show with WriteLine or appending the message to a multiline TextBox.

System.Text.StringBuilder messageBoxCS = new System.Text.StringBuilder();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();

}

    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "ToolTipSize", e.ToolTipSize)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "Cancel", e.Cancel)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()

End Sub
  • ToolTipSize

    Gets or sets the size of the ToolTip.

    public System.Drawing.Size ToolTipSize { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • Size

      The Size of the ToolTip window.

    Remarks

    The ToolTipSize property enables the Popup event handler to change the size of the ToolTip window. ToolTipSize is often used in conjunction with the members of the DrawToolTipEventArgs class to customize the appearance of ToolTips.

    Example

    The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip.Popup event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing Show with WriteLine or appending the message to a multiline TextBox.

    To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type ToolTip named ToolTip1. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip.Popup event. 

    private void ToolTip1_Popup(Object sender, PopupEventArgs e) {

System.Text.StringBuilder messageBoxCS = new System.Text.StringBuilder();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "ToolTipSize", e.ToolTipSize );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
messageBoxCS.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "Cancel", e.Cancel );
messageBoxCS.AppendLine();
MessageBox.Show(messageBoxCS.ToString(), "Popup Event" );
}

    Private Sub ToolTip1_Popup(sender as Object, e as PopupEventArgs) _ 
     Handles ToolTip1.Popup

    Dim messageBoxVB as New System.Text.StringBuilder()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedWindow", e.AssociatedWindow)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "AssociatedControl", e.AssociatedControl)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "IsBalloon", e.IsBalloon)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "ToolTipSize", e.ToolTipSize)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    messageBoxVB.AppendFormat("{0} = {1}", "Cancel", e.Cancel)
    messageBoxVB.AppendLine()
    MessageBox.Show(messageBoxVB.ToString(),"Popup Event")

End Sub
